content:
re :I have experimented with the ports and settings.

You can only use whatever the server dictates.

However, when you ask a question, you need to supply information in the addtitional text area. So others can understand your setup.

Such as : What OS are you using? - Answers may need to be tailored to specific OS. What version of Thunderbird are you using? There are different modification depending upon version, so we may need to adjust responses.

What server are you talking about? Are you using an Imap or Pop account ?

If you are getting an error message then please upload an image of error message OR type the error message Word for Word verbatim.

Supply information on your current server settings....such as: Upload images that show your 'Account Settings' > 'Server Settings' for the problem account and also SMTP server settings.

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Account' section
  • Either post an image showing the contents of that section OR copy paste all the contents and paste data into this forum question.

Please post that info and in the meantime check the following so we can be sure they are not blocking things.

Firewall: Access Firewall - it might be the defaulton computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus prgram. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program.

VPN: Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some peopl who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use). Gmail, Spectrum, and many other servers do not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address. Servers presumes you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. Confirm VPN is switched off
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
'Block' has a very specific meaning. I presume you mean do not accept mail from x email address. However, the server is bound to accept mail sent to you and Thunderbird has no control over the server, it just displays emails and can sort incoming mail automatically into specific folders.

The server will accept any emails sent to your email address. You may be able to set up a rule on the server (via webmail account) to choose whether a sender is a safe sender or not. Usually, the server will put those emails from the unsafe sender directly into the server 'Spam' folder.

In any email client: Pop mail accounts can only access the server Inbox and download whatever has not previously been downloaded to the Pop account Inbox.

If you do not want to see whatever the server puts in the server/webmail Spam folder then a Pop account will not display anything in server Spam folder as it cannot access it. Most servers tend to auto empty the server Spam folder periodically. But do check out that this does occur otherwise you would need to periodically loggon to webmail account and manaully empty it yourself.

In a way this is a workaround so you do not see emails in Thunderbird Pop account if server has already put them in server Spam folder.

Imap accounts subscribe to see server folders and can only display whatever is those server folders. As folders synchronise with server, they act as if one and the same. You basically are seeing a mirror image of your webmail account.

In Thunderbird you have some options: You can set up the Account Settings > Junk/Spam Settings for each account and train the Adaptive Junk/Spam controls to auto recognise what is and what is not spam. It would be important to set up your address books as whitelists and make sure the unwanted email address is not in any of those address books.

Another alternative In Thunderbird, you can create a Message Filter.

  • Tools > Message Filters
  • Click on 'New'
  • Give filter a suitable name like 'Block senders'
  • Select 'Getting new mail' and 'Filter before Junk Classification'
  • Select 'Match ANY of the following' - that means you can set up more than one email address which you want to auto delete or send to spam.
  • 'From' and 'contains' and enter email address
  • to add another click on + icon and repeat except enter a different email address.

Perform these actions: Suggest you use any of these options

  • 'Set junk Status to ' and 'Junk'
  • 'Move message to' and 'Spam on account name'

OR

  • 'Delete Message'

OR

  • 'Move message to' and select 'Deleted on account name'
  • Click on 'OK'

Put filter at top of list as the filter operate from the top downwards. Make sure filter is selected as enabled.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
> Have you tried removing your antivirus email scanning?

The simple test for this is the following...

  • Start Windows in safe mode with networking enabled - https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode
  • Still In Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Does problem change?

If it did not get better, try changing the hidden preference accessibility.force_disabled to 1.

If it did not get better then cause is either: bug in Thunderbird, a setting, file or folder (something) in your Thunderbird profile, your mail provider. Please attach to the bug report or support topic a file created from Help | Troubleshooting | copy text to clipboard

If it did get better , then (still in Windows safe mode) ... start Thunderbird normally -- If problem is still gone, then cause is likely a program loaded during windows startup. Possibilities include: antivirus software (AV), virus/malware, background downloads such as Windows or other program updates, to name a few. For AV information see https://wiki.mozilla.org/Thunderbird:Testing:Antivirus_Related_Performance_Issues -- If problem came back, then cause is likely a Thunderbird add-on - eliminate them by disabling add-ons one at a time in Tools | add-ons | extensions and restart Thunderbird after disabling (if you have many add-ons, try disabling half of them at a time)

- If results are unclear ... possibilities include temporary conditions such as contention from other running programs, downloads related to windows update, ...

Please let us know your findings.

content:
Have you considered you are probably suffering from a slow upload speed. Internet services routinely limit uploads to around 10% of their advertised download speed. It is how they differentiate between their commercial/business class of products (which as usually symmetrical) and residential ones. So you might have a fast download speed, but uploads might be a very different picture.

BTW just how large is the attachment you are sending (they grow about 30% when attached to an email.) You might be better of uploading the file using one of the providers for Thunderbird filelink and only actually sending links to the file in the email rather than the entire file. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/filelink-large-attachments

content:
Can we start with you have a problem and I do not. I did nothing special, just my computer (Windows) and hence my locale settings set the date format of my country. If your date is not set correctly then most likely there is a reason for this and it is not sloppy programming in Thunderbird.

There is a setting in the calendar for dates. But that is not used in the user interface beyond the calendar, General dates are implemented via the system locale. On Linux where nothing can be assumed and every distribution is different as if every distribution method. The locale is set generally using two methods. One is in the GUI windowing environment and is what most Windows refugees will be relying on. There is another in the underlying system and they do not necessarily talk to one another. Personally I think it is just another reason the much talked of year of Linux on the desktop is still not here. They can not standardize on anything and there has to a customization feature to break any standard that does emerge. But I digress. You need to examine the locale setting of your system using the command line. Thunderbird uses system settings not windowing environment settings.

This page appears to offer a fairly comprehensive overview https://www.tecmint.com/set-system-locales-in-linux/

For a start you appear top have forgotten to mention that this is on some Linux distribution.

content:
Try this:

  1. click file>offline>download to ensure all messages are downloaded
  2. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  3. rightclick and scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  4. exit thunderbird
  5. click the the imapmail\<IMAP account folder>
  6. COPY all desired folders to be uploaded and store in mail\Local Folders folder
  7. restart thunderbird and check that all folders are functional
  8. highlight one folder to be uploaded, rightclick, and select COPY to the desired Outlook account. (If the folder is huge, it may be prudent to copy small groups at a time, or to create a manual filter for this. IMAP was not designed for high volume uploads.)
  9. after the copy, check that the online folder is complete.
  10. repeat the two previous steps for each desired folder.
  11. after all have been uploaded, you may delete the Local Folders.

content:
Let's first confirm that the file system on the external drive is the issue.

  1. Open File Explorer.
  2. Right-click on the external drive.
  3. Select Properties.
  4. The File system will be listed under the General tab.

What is the file system?

There are messy ways of reducing the size of your inbox. The only unmessy one is to delete messages from it and then compact the folder.

But you'll want to make a back-up before you do anything like that. Can you at least copy your profile folder to another location on your internal drive before deleting messages? Access your profile in the file system by using the Help menu > Troubleshooting information > Profile Folder > Show in [...]

Do you have another external drive that you can format to use the ex-FAT file system? Can you re-format this drive to use ex-FAT?

If you can do that, you won't have to delete messages and you can continue using the normal process for transfering a profile to a new computer.

Another approach would be to move half the messages in your inbox to a local folder. But moving them back into the inbox on your new computer and syncing with the server might take a long time and may not be reliable. I don't know.

Apologies if I'm missing something obvious. . . Thanks again for the help.
creator: TbirdUser53

content: Before anything else, with which application do you want to open .HEIC files? The .heic file extension stands for High Efficiency Image Container. It is the file format used by Apple for photos on iPhones and iPads (running iOS 11 or later) and Macs. To open it with Windows 10/11 it requires the "HEIF Image Extensions" from the Microsoft Store. So you'd need to get this sorted first. To test it, you can save the .heic attachment to your local disk, and open it with whatever application is needed. Once you can open .heic files successfully on your Windows computer, we can get back to the Thunderbird issue.
creator: christ1

content: Hello, from File Explorer I open HEIC files regularly with the Photos app. It appears my challenge here is getting the proper linkage between Thunderbird attachment content type and Windows Photos app, for example. Somehow, the current linkage is to Adobe Acrobat where HEIC is an unsupported file type.
creator: TbirdUser53

content:
Yeah are we dealing with yet another case is file extensions are meaningless and folks just do not understand that? I am guessing the answer to that is yes.

HEIC is a proprietary file format as Christ has stated of Apple computers, unfortunately most Apple users are unaware the rest of the world struggles with it just as historically most Outlook users were unaware they sent proprietary email formats that arrived in folks inboxes as winmail.dat attachments. Only outlook could read them.

For the internet and Thunderbird (windows is another state and your reference to file explorer is Windows not email or the internet where media types rule. For a file to be recognized as a particular type the file type must be declared correctly in the attachment, not in the file extension.

The list of media type is here https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml

The media types for HEIC are given as image/heif [ISO-IEC_JTC_1][David_Singer] heif-sequence image/heif-sequenc

I have no idea what either actually is and do not need to. What is relevant here is to open the source of your received email (ctrl+U) and find (ctrl+F) HEIC and see if the media type of the attachment in the message source is correctly stated or some garbage value that denoted the file type as say a binary stream (exceedingly common where windows programmers are asked to do email because the concept of media types in not in the Microsoft vocabulary IMO.) If the media type is not correctly stated there is nothing to be done, except perhaps find on of the open by extension Thunderbird addons if such exist for your version of Thunderbird such as https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/EN-us/thunderbird/addon/openattachmentbyextension/ or you could get the email sender to correctly encode their emails.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Progress is being made. When I opened the Email source and searched for HEIC I did find that it appears the media type of the attachment is correctly stated:

Content-Type: image/heic; name="IMG_3143.heic" Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="IMG_3143.heic" Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64 Content-ID: <19b2f0b7679caba132c1> X-Attachment-Id: 19b2f0b7679caba132c1

Since clicking the attachment tried to open the HEIC attachment with Adobe Acrobat, I went into settings for Content Type and removed all mention of Adobe Acrobat and set these items to Always Ask. I then clicked an HEIC attachment and was prompted for the app to use to open. After some searching, I found both Paint and Photos and set Paint as the app to use and also selected Always Use this app.

When checking back in the Thunderbird Content Type table, I found that Content Type JPG File has been changed from Always Ask to Use mspaint.exe as shown in the attached image. I'm not sure why the JPG File content was chosen but HEIC files now always open with Paint when clicked. Is this a bug? Should not the JPG File content type remain Always Ask and a "new" content type of HEIC be "added" with Action of Use mspaint.exe? I'm confused as to why this works as it does. Any recommendations? Thank you.

I am using TB 145.0 (64 bit) and Win11.

So far, I can open the HEIC file with Paint as desired but I suppose all JPG files will now open with Paint which is not what I desire for the longer term.
creator: TbirdUser53

content:
I'm not sure why the JPG File content was chosen but HEIC files now always open with Paint when clicked.

I'm not sure sure it's related. I'd just delete the unwanted content type.
creator: christ1

content:
Thanks, the problem has been solved. I deleted the JPG content action and then opened an HEIC file and established the action I wanted and HEIC was added to the content list. I then opened a JPG file and established the action I wanted, see image below.

I'm not sure why there was "interference" initially and things are now working as desired. Thanks to all!
creator: TbirdUser53

content:
If you are using an imap account then check you have subscribed to see those folders. In Folder Pane...

  • Right click on the imap mail account name folder and select 'Subscribe'.
  • Make sure all the folders you want to see are selected and click on 'Ok'
  • Check the 'Account Settings' > 'Copies & Folders' for the imap account.

Example:

  • Select: 'Place a copy in'
  • Select 'Other' and choose the correct 'Sent folder on the imap account name'

check you have also selected to download full copies:

  • 'Account Settings' > Synchronisation & Storage'
  • click on 'Advanced' button and make sure all folders that you want to download full copies are selected.

Also check you have the following selected: Using the 'Menu Bar' toolbar (that's the one with 'File, Edit, View, Go, Message etc')

  • View > Folders > select 'All' - uncheck all the others.

If you are using 'Unified' Folders then check to see whether all the 'sent' fodlers for all the accounts are selected.

  • Right click on the 'Sent' Unified folder and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Choose' and for each mail account make sure the accounts 'Sent' or 'Sent Mail' - whatever it's called is selected. Click on 'Update.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
the first message indicates that Thunderbird can access the internet as it can access the ISPDB, it has also fetched the settings to the local machine of offered them for your review. But as your second image indicated the credentials as offered do not work.

Why? This is a somewhat bland but common issue and most frequently it leads directly to an antivirus/security product that thinks it is protecting you from yourself. Is there an email scanner in your antivirus product? make sure it is turned off. They are terrible things at the best of times and a complete roadblock at others with their self signed certificates that Thunderbird does not recognize and man-in-the-middle hacking techniques for encrypted communications scanning.

Generally I suggest a short term disabling of any third party antivirus products while setting up accounts. Windows defender does not appear to be a problem child and is active while the third party products are disabled.

content:
Puzzling. For the past few years, my suggested steps have worked for many. Important that thunderbird not be running when the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder is copied. The only accounts where I have to reset is where there are app passwords. If possible, I suggest starting over. The steps I use are these:


https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
I am guessing you are in a country where that language is the default. The web site automatically allocates a language based on where you connect from. The text appears to be Spanish, so in spain for the weekend perhaps?

The links in the URL at the top of the web pages show the language and you can override the detected values with manual links.

For instance. This link will be in US English as it is explicitly stated in the link (the official language of Mozilla is EN_US and is the base language others are translated from. Amusingly for me that means EN_GB is translated from US English.) https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/mozilla-account/accounts This link will be auto detected based on your location (IP address based so a VPN can cause havoc) hhttps://support.mozilla.org/products/mozilla-account/accounts This link will be in Spanish as it is explicitly stated in the link https://support.mozilla.org/es/products/mozilla-account/accounts

All translations from English to other languages are not complete, so English text frequently pops up in untranslated articles.

content:
First, the name isn't important, so long as Thunderbird can find it. Try this:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformaation
  2. scroll down to 'profiles and click 'about:profiles'
  3. click the 'create profile' button in upper left
  4. click next
  5. enter a shortcut name, such as MYPROFILE
  6. notice profile name slightly below that line - click 'choose folder' and then 'finish'
  7. the folder now appears in the list. click 'Open Folder'
  8. paste 100% of the contents of your old profile here, replacing all content.
  9. now click the 'launch' button
  10. if all goes well, your profile is now active.

content: There are no accounts there. We may have the wrong profile, so here's another approach to try: - exit thunderbird if running - enter %appdata% in the windows task bar search box and press enter. that should open the appdata\roaming window. - paste the rescued appdata\roaming\thunderbird to overlay the existing appdata\roaming thunderbird. you will be prompted for overwrite. - now restart thunderbird and let me know results. This should work if the profile is complete. (NOTE: Be sure you don't just append the thunderbird folder. sometimes users paste over appdata\roaming\thunderbird, which creates appdata\roaming\thunderbird\thunderbird. )

content:
Open .msg file "natively" Nejde o dotaz na podporu, ale o návrh nové funkce (feature request). Kam to patří: Bugzilla Mozilla → projekt Thunderbird (typ: Enhancement).

Podpora řeší existující funkce. Nativní otevření .msg (Outlook) včetně příloh a možnosti „Odpovědět“ je nové rozšíření Thunderbirdu. Formát .msg je proprietární, proto je implementace složitá a spíše dlouhodobá.
Podpora .msg je dlouhodobě komplikovaná kvůli proprietárnímu formátu Microsoftu. Existují doplňky (ImportExportTools NG), ale nejde o plnohodnotné „nativní“ řešení. Šance na implementaci není nulová, ale je spíše dlouhodobá a závislá na kapacitách vývojářů. Zde je přímý odkaz na Bugzilla Mozilla pro založení návrhu nové funkce (Enhancement) pro Thunderbird: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/enter_bug.cgi?product=Thunderbird Na této stránce zvolíš typ „Enhancement“ a příslušnou komponentu (např. Message Reader).
creator: poljos-moz

content:
There is no AI here. Despite someone accusing me of being an AI yesterday.

One of the problems with AI is it is only as good as the database it uses to generate it's answers. With something dynamic like the copying of Thunderbird profile (it has changed repeatedly in recent years) the AI is worse than useless because they apparently have no concept of "current"

open Thunderbird on the machine you wish to update. Goto the troubleshooting information on the help menu and click the show profile button in the first block of troubleshooting information.

Close Thunderbird once the windows file manager opens. Now copy you old profile data (that will be in a folder with one of the files being prefs.js) in to replace the files and folders in the profile Thunderbird just opened. You will be asked to replace files. If you are not you are not doing it correctly.

Once the copy is completed restart Thunderbird. You are done.

Alternatively you could use the troubleshooting information on your donor computer to just identify the actual profile folder in use that needs to be copied (including all sub folders. No guessing required this way.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Didn't mean to imply you were AI; I appreciate your help. Found something that had me copy an entire folder named Thunderbird to the desktop. Was a day or two ago, and I'm old, so I don't remember the exact location of the folder on my desktop. I think C:\Users\dalew\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird and the "clone" on my Desktop seems to work. If that won't work, let me know and I'll follow what ever instructions you have. One thing I noticed about AI, mainly using Copilot, is that the answers it gives are not "up-to-date." It starts by giving "older" data that is not pertinent to today. You end up getting answers that apply to historical app versions. If you keep things up-to-date, as I generally do, you end up getting several messages that don't apply to your situation. I'm slowly adding "as of today" to my questions to get pertinent answers. Usually get better results.
creator: dalewebb1

content:
TRy this if you are having a problem.

Make sure you have the same version of Thunderbird on both computers. Do you did not mention whether you got Thunderbird from Windows app store or whether you downloaded from website. This info is important as it effects where the profile is stored. I'm going to assume you got it from the website for both laptop and desktop:

On Desktop computer Firewall Access Firewall - either the default on computer OR it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. Make sure Thunderbird program has been set up as 'allowed'

VPN Check desktop does not have a VPN enabled. There are many Anti=Virus products that now provide VPN an I have come across many cases where it had been auto enabled. Switch off VPN.

Now to get copy/clone of laptop 'Thunderbird' onto desktop computer.

Computer Laptop

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important
  • In windows search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to external device

Computer desktop

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important
  • In windows search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'

If you had run Thunderbird the first time it will have created a default Thunderbird folder

  • Delete that new 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Paste the copied 'Thunderbird' folder into the 'Roaming' folder.

start Thunderbird.

PS: Matts advice on AI is good. I tend to stay well clear of it.
creator: Toad-Hall
